description: From Latin expeditatus, past participle of expeditare (“to expeditate”), from ex (“out”) + ped- (“foot”).

verbs.description: expeditate (third-person singular simple present expeditates, present participle expeditating, simple past and past participle expeditated)

entries.meaning: (UK, obsolete, transitive, law, forest law) To deprive of the claws or the balls of the forefeet.
examples: They expeditated the dogs, to stop them chasing deer.
